pull_request.title: fix(ci_visibility): add safety checks and exception handling around _fetch_tests_to_skip
pull_request.body:
Prevents a poorly-structured (but still valid JSON) response from causing an exception while fetching tests to skip.

An uncaught exception would cause the test runner to crash. The "bare" `except` is probably overly broad (based on the code, I can only see `AttributeError`, `KeyError` or `TypeError` exceptions), but since the goal is to prevent crashing the test runner, I think the broad except makes sense.

No release note because ITR is in beta.

## Checklist

- [x] Change(s) are motivated and described in the PR description.
- [x] Testing strategy is described if automated tests are not included in the PR.
- [x] Risk is outlined (performance impact, potential for breakage, maintainability, etc).
- [x] Change is maintainable (easy to change, telemetry, documentation).
- [x] [Library release note guidelines](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/stable/releasenotes.html) are followed. If no release note is required, add label `changelog/no-changelog`.
- [x] Documentation is included (in-code, generated user docs, [public corp docs](https://github.com/DataDog/documentation/)).
- [x] Backport labels are set (if [applicable](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html#backporting))

## Reviewer Checklist

- [x] Title is accurate.
- [x] No unnecessary changes are introduced.
- [x] Description motivates each change.
- [x] Avoids breaking [API](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/stable/versioning.html#interfaces) changes unless absolutely necessary.
- [x] Testing strategy adequately addresses listed risk(s).
- [x] Change is maintainable (easy to change, telemetry, documentation).
- [x] Release note makes sense to a user of the library.
- [x] Reviewer has explicitly acknowledged and discussed the performance implications of this PR as reported in the benchmarks PR comment.
- [x] Backport labels are set in a manner that is consistent with the [release branch maintenance policy](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html#backporting)
- [x] If this PR touches code that signs or publishes builds or packages, or handles credentials of any kind, I've requested a review from `@DataDog/security-design-and-guidance`.
- [x] This PR doesn't touch any of that.

commits.message:
fix(ci_visibility): use custom configurations when querying ITR skippable tests endpoint (#7329)

Fixes the fact that [custom
configurations](https://docs.datadoghq.com/continuous_integration/tests/#custom-configurations)
were not properly being applied when querying the Intelligent Test
Runner skippable endpoint.

Now, `DD_TAGS` tags starting with `test.configuration` will be supplied
to the ITR skippable endpoint under the
`data.attributes.configurations.custom` object. Since the object is only
populated when the custom configurations tags are found, there is no
change in behavior for customers that were not using them. For customers
who are using them, ITR may (temporarily) not find skippable tests until
coverage using the new custom configurations are found.

No release note because ITR is still in beta.

## Checklist

- [x] Change(s) are motivated and described in the PR description.
- [x] Testing strategy is described if automated tests are not included
in the PR.
- [x] Risk is outlined (performance impact, potential for breakage,
maintainability, etc).
- [x] Change is maintainable (easy to change, telemetry, documentation).
- [x] [Library release note
guidelines](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/stable/releasenotes.html)
are followed. If no release note is required, add label
`changelog/no-changelog`.
- [x] Documentation is included (in-code, generated user docs, [public
corp docs](https://github.com/DataDog/documentation/)).
- [x] Backport labels are set (if
[applicable](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html#backporting))

chore(asm): django automatic login events updates (#7281)

## Description

This updates Django automatic login events to the latest state of the
RFC, which changed some things. It also includes some fixes related with
testing about the latest version of the system tests, which are now all
passing for Django on the branch that will be published soon (both
normal and extended versions).

ci: run framework tests if frameworks.yml modified (#7379)

Currently if you just edit only test_frameworks.yml, we won't actually
run those tests, which keeps PRs that do this from being merged since
the tests don't run e.g.:
https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-py/pull/7374
With this change we check if this file is changed, if so, we make sure
to run them.

## Checklist

- [x] Change(s) are motivated and described in the PR description.
- [x] Testing strategy is described if automated tests are not included
in the PR.

pull_request.title: fix(ci): filter user credentials from SSH git repo URLs
pull_request.body:
## Motivation

While `dd-trace-py` filters user credentials such as usernames and passwords from HTTPS git repository URLs, this does not happen with SSH git repository URLs.

This PR aims to filter user credentials from SSH git repo URLs.

## Checklist

- [X] Change(s) are motivated and described in the PR description.
- [X] Testing strategy is described if automated tests are not included in the PR.

pull_request.title: chore(ci): move slotscheck and conftests
pull_request.body:
We move the slotscheck and conftests jobs to after the `pre_check` job has completed.

This is to reduce the duration time of `pre_check` and not delay the start of integration test suites.

comment.body: My feeling is that if we went with the standard "GIL release on I/O" approach we could save the extra logic required to keep note of the thread activity. This is already done on the Python side by the PeriodicService class anyway. So I feel it would make the code slightly easier to reason about.

pull_request.title: fix(profiler): make ddup uploader thread safe
pull_request.body:
The ddup extension, which is a wrapper over the libdatadog exporter, provides a double-buffering strategy in order to minimize application wait-time.

Unfortunately, that double-buffering strategy was faulty.
* uploading thread had a `static` lifetime in the C++ wrapper
* atexit handlers mandate the destruction of objects with static initialization
* At the same time, Python schedules a last-ditch upload using a detached thread
* `~std::thread()` ends up calling an invalidate `std::terminate()`, which raises into a sigabrt.

This strategy attempts to fix this defect
* Move the uploader thread into the ddup Upload object, wrapped in an Optional
* Create a `std::atomic<bool>` to track the working state of the thread
* Add a synchronization point (yield/sleep) at the top of `upload()` to ensure only a single uploader is active

## Checklist

- [X] Change(s) are motivated and described in the PR description.
- [X] Testing strategy is described if automated tests are not included in the PR.
- [X] Risk is outlined (performance impact, potential for breakage, maintainability, etc).

- [X] Documentation is included (in-code, generated user docs, [public corp docs](https://github.com/DataDog/documentation/)).
- [X] Backport labels are set (if [applicable](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html#backporting))

ensure only a single uploader is active

pull_request.title: fix(profiler): make ddup uploader thread safe
pull_request.body:
The ddup extension, which is a wrapper over the libdatadog exporter, provides a double-buffering strategy in order to minimize application wait-time.

Unfortunately, that double-buffering strategy was faulty.
* uploading thread had a `static` lifetime in the C++ wrapper
* atexit handlers mandate the destruction of objects with static initialization
* At the same time, Python schedules a last-ditch upload using a detached thread
* `~std::thread()` ends up calling an invalidate `std::terminate()`, which raises into a sigabrt.

This strategy attempts to fix this defect
* Move the uploader thread into the ddup Upload object, wrapped in an Optional
* Create a `std::atomic<bool>` to track the working state of the thread
* Add a synchronization point (yield/sleep) at the top of `upload()` to ensure only a single uploader is active

issue.title: fix(ci): filter user credentials from SSH git repo URLs
issue.body:
## Motivation

While `dd-trace-py` filters user credentials such as usernames and passwords from HTTPS git repository URLs, this does not happen with SSH git repository URLs.

This PR aims to filter user credentials from SSH git repo URLs.

pull_request.title: chore: migrate to ruff
pull_request.body:
We migrate to ruff as a drop-in replacement for isort and flake8.

We try our best to match the existing results from isort and flake8 but do make minimal changes as necessary.

**BEFORE:**

```
$ time hatch run lint:isort --check --diff .
Skipped 21 files

real    0m3.556s
user    0m2.030s
sys     0m1.047s
$ time hatch run lint:flake8

real    0m42.019s
user    0m40.353s
sys     0m1.261s
```

**AFTER:**

```
$ time hatch run lint:ruff check --diff .

real    0m0.864s
user    0m0.813s
sys     0m0.234s
```


## Checklist

- [x] Change(s) are motivated and described in the PR description.
- [x] Testing strategy is described if automated tests are not included in the PR.
- [x] Risk is outlined (performance impact, potential for breakage, maintainability, etc).
- [x] Change is maintainable (easy to change, telemetry, documentation).
- [x] [Library release note guidelines](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/stable/releasenotes.html) are followed. If no release note is required, add label `changelog/no-changelog`.

issue.title: ddtrace 2.1.0 causes test to hang
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for taking the time for reporting an issue!

Before reporting an issue on dd-trace-py, please be sure to provide all
necessary information.

If you're hitting a bug, make sure that you're using the latest version of this
library.
-->

### Summary of problem

A test that runs fine in ddtrace-py 2.0.5 hangs forever with 2.1.0 (and any 2.1.x version).

### Which version of dd-trace-py are you using?

- 2.0.5: everything ok
- 2.1.0: hangs
- 2.1.3: hangs

### Which version of pip are you using?

N/A


### Which libraries and their versions are you using?

<details>
  <summary>`pip freeze`</summary>
  <!-- Paste output of pip freeze here -->
</details>

### How can we reproduce your problem?

```python
# test_hang.py

from click.testing import CliRunner
from freezegun import freeze_time
from clickfile import hang

def test_hang():
    frozen_time = datetime(year=2022, month=1, day=1, hour=13, minute=37)
    with freeze_time(frozen_time):
        CliRunner().invoke(hang)
```

```python
# clickfile.py

@cli.command()
@tracer.wrap(service="foo", resource="bar")
def hang():
    pass
```

### What is the result that you get?

The command `pytest -k test_hang` hangs forever on ddtrace 2.1.x but runs fine on 2.0.x.

### What is the result that you expected?

No hanging.

commits.message:
chore(asm): django automatic login events updates (#7281)

## Description

This updates Django automatic login events to the latest state of the
RFC, which changed some things. It also includes some fixes related with
testing about the latest version of the system tests, which are now all
passing for Django on the branch that will be published soon (both
normal and extended versions).

## Checklist

- [X] Change(s) are motivated and described in the PR description.
- [X] Testing strategy is described if automated tests are not included
in the PR.
- [X] Risk is outlined (performance impact, potential for breakage,
maintainability, etc).
- [X] Change is maintainable (easy to change, telemetry, documentation).
- [X] [Library release note
guidelines](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/stable/releasenotes.html)
are followed. If no release note is required, add label
`changelog/no-changelog`.
- [X] Documentation is included (in-code, generated user docs, [public
corp docs](https://github.com/DataDog/documentation/)).
- [X] Backport labels are set (if
[applicable](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html#backporting))

## Reviewer Checklist

- [x] Title is accurate.
- [x] No unnecessary changes are introduced.
- [x] Description motivates each change.
- [x] Avoids breaking
[API](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/stable/versioning.html#interfaces)
changes unless absolutely necessary.
- [x] Testing strategy adequately addresses listed risk(s).
- [x] Change is maintainable (easy to change, telemetry, documentation).
- [x] Release note makes sense to a user of the library.
- [x] Reviewer has explicitly acknowledged and discussed the performance
implications of this PR as reported in the benchmarks PR comment.
- [x] Backport labels are set in a manner that is consistent with the
[release branch maintenance
policy](https://ddtrace.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html#backporting)
- [x] If this PR touches code that signs or publishes builds or
packages, or handles credentials of any kind, I've requested a review
from `@DataDog/security-design-and-guidance`.
- [x] This PR doesn't touch any of that.

---------

Signed-off-by: Juanjo Alvarez <juanjo.alvarezmartinez@datadoghq.com>
Co-authored-by: Alberto Vara <alberto.vara@datadoghq.com>
Co-authored-by: Tahir H. Butt <tahir.butt@datadoghq.com>

ci: run framework tests if frameworks.yml modified (#7379)

Currently if you just edit only test_frameworks.yml, we won't actually
run those tests, which keeps PRs that do this from being merged since
the tests don't run e.g.:
https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-py/pull/7374
With this change we check if this file is changed, if so, we make sure
to run them.

## Checklist

- [x] Change(s) are motivated and described in the PR description.
- [x] Testing strategy is described if automated tests are not included
in the PR.

issue.title: fix(appsec): transfer-encoding chunked requests are dropped
issue.body:
https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-py/pull/7377 reverts https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-py/pull/7266. This change instead is an attempt at the proper fix needed to support `Transfer-Encoding: chunked` requests in appsec.

comment.body:
## Benchmarks

Benchmark execution time: 2023-10-27 08:47:07

Comparing candidate commit 7fb6699b525307224ecdd5b6a623ba88e8a657d2 in PR branch `APPSEC-11740-fix-wsgi-input-read` with baseline commit d67bfc36e0455d262e21e9e2e24b2167b273aa0b in branch `2.x`.

Found 0 performance improvements and 0 performance regressions! Performance is the same for 90 metrics, 0 unstable metrics.
